text: [Music]
I think there is a real possibility that
if we're successful in being able to
establish a long-term colony on Mars
that it could actually lead us down a
path where a new human species evolved
on Mars and the reason is that as far as
we understand new species evolve most
commonly when populations become
isolated from one another and those
populations aren't able to come together
make and produce offspring those people
that are living on Mars will be able to
adapt to the conditions on Mars which
are very different from the conditions
on earth so that could lead to a
situation where people who are living on
Mars are actually evolving in a way that
is different from the way humans are
evolving back on earth and what's more
because there's no microbial life on
Mars as far as we know there's a
possibility that we could actually start
to eliminate infectious diseases caused
by microorganisms among people living on
Mars
the only microbes that would be there
would be the ones that we take with us
so if we take precautions to not
introduce microorganism to Mars
especially those that cause disease and
if we make a decision to not bring
animals that are reservoirs of disease
then we might be able to avoid
additional infections new infections in
the future so if you have people living
on Mars that evolved to the point where
they lose their immune system or become
less effective it could make it really
dangerous for people coming from Earth
to Mars because they might accidentally
introduce a new disease so that leads us
to a situation where you have people
living on Mars and people living on
earth and they don't interact with one
another because of the fear of starting
an epidemic on Mars in that situation it
would be very likely that people living
on Mars actually evolved independently
and could eventually become a new
species
[Music]
